questions.question: A 62-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and recent hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and is provided below. Which of the following is the most likely primary source of this lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Renal cell carcinoma Explanation: Renal cell carcinoma is a common cause of cannonball metastases due to its vascular nature and tendency for hematogenous spread. It presents as large, well-defined pulmonary nodules. Patients with RCC commonly have associated symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, or palpable mass, but lung metastases can often be the initial presentation in advanced cases. The cannonball appearance is characteristic of metastatic RCC on chest imaging. Cannonball Metastases: Cannonball

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic liver disease presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and mild chest discomfort over the past few weeks. On examination, there is decreased bilateral breath sound intensity with dullness on percussion at the lung bases. A chest X-ray shows the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Congestive Heart Failure with Pleural Effusion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bilateral Hydrothorax Explanation: In this case, the clinical picture and imaging findings suggest a diagnosis of bilateral hydrothorax, particularly given the patient’s background of chronic liver disease. Hepatic hydrothorax can develop in patients with advanced liver disease due to transudative fluid accumulation, often through diaphragmatic defects, into the pleural spaces. The absence of air-fluid levels, along with bilaterally homogeneous pleural fluid without signs of infection, supports the diagnosis of hydrothorax over other options. Bilateral Hydrothorax: Hepatic hydrothorax is a pleural effusion often associated with advanced liver disease. It presents as transudative pleural effusions, most commonly on the right but can be bilateral. Pathophysiologically, ascitic fluid moves across diaphragmatic defects into the pleural space due to pressure gradients. Bilateral hydrothorax, characterized by transudative fluid accumulation in the pleural space on both sides, can be caused by several other conditions. Common causes: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) - due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation, leading to transudative pleural effusions. Nephrotic Syndrome: Severe hypoalbuminemia leads to decreased oncotic pressure, causing fluid to accumulate in various body spaces, including the pleural space. Hypothyroidism: Severe hypothyroidism can cause generalized fluid

questions.question: A 65-year-old man visits OPD with the following presentation as shown in the image. His chest CT shows bronchiectasis. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this patient's digital finding?

options.A: The condition involves proliferation of connective tissue at the nail base
options.B: It can be associated with cystic fibrosis and lung cancer
options.C: The condition always indicates irreversible tissue changes
options.D: The pathogenesis involves platelet-derived growth factors

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The condition always indicates irreversible tissue changes Explanation: The image shows typical findings of clubbing of fingers, seen in various cardiopulmonary conditions. Clubbing is not always irreversible and can be reversible in certain conditions. Clubbing of Fingers Definition • Enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes • Proliferation of connective tissue (Option A) • Particularly on dorsal surface • Changes at base of clubbed nail Pathophysiology • Connective tissue proliferation • Exact mechanism unknown • Platelet-derived growth factors implicated (Option D) Clinical Signs Bulbous Enlargement of the Distal Phalanges Loss of the Normal Angle Between the Nail and the Nailbed (Lovibond’s Angle) Increased Sponginess of the Soft Tissue at the Base of the Nail Nail Changes: Nail flattening / nail curvature Hippocratic fingers : The tips of the fingers become enlarged, and the nails curve downward Clinical tests Schamroth’s Sign: Normal : A small diamond-shaped window should be visible between the nails when the fingers are positioned in this way. Positive Schamroth’s Sign : The window disappears, and there is no gap between the nails, indicating the loss of the normal angle at the nail bed. Associated Conditions • Cyanotic congenital heart disease • Infective endocarditis • Bronchiectasis • Cystic Fibrosis (Option B) • Lung cancer • Tuberculosis • Inflammatory bowel disease Key Features • Can be hereditary or acquired • May be reversible in certain circumstances • Associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy • Can cause pain and arthritis-like changes Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 275

questions.question: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with chest trauma. He is in severe respiratory distress with BP 80/50 mmHg, HR 142/min, RR 32/min. Physical examination reveals absent breath sounds. The X-ray is attached below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: CT Head for identifying possible cerebral injury

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Immediate needle decompression Explanation: The case presents a classic presentation of tension pneumothorax, characterized by: Severe respiratory distress Hypotension (BP 80/50) Tachycardia (HR 142) Absent breath sounds and hyperresonance Tracheal deviation to contralateral side History of trauma Also, X-ray shows tension pneumothorax with absent lung markings on the lateral side of the right pleural cavity and a collapsed right lung. The trachea and heart are displaced toward the left indicating a mediastinal shift. The presence of mediastinal shift with hypotension is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention. The positive pleural pressure and mediastinal shift in tension pneumothorax can lead to cardiovascular collapse if not treated promptly. questions.question: A 68-year-old female receiving a blood transfusion for severe anemia develops acute dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypertension 30 minutes into the transfusion. Her blood pressure is 168/95 mmHg, and chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Which of the following represents the most appropriate immediate management?

options.A: Continue transfusion but at a slower rate

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Stop transfusion and administer diuretics Explanation: This case presents classic symptoms of Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) : TACO is a common and underrecognized transfusion adverse reaction Clinical features include dyspnea, hypertension, bilateral crackles Management explicitly requires stopping the transfusion and administration of O2 and diuretics Risk factors include pre existing fluid overload and cardiac dysfunction Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) Definition Common and underrecognized transfusion adverse reaction Incidence 1-10% per RBC transfusion Risk Factors • Preexisting fluid overload • Cardiac dysfunction • Large volume of RBCs • Excessive rate of transfusion Clinical Features • Dyspnea • Hypertension • Bilateral crackles • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide Prevention in High-Risk Patients • Slow transfusion rate (RBCC over 3-4 h) • Close monitoring Management • Stop transfusion • Administer O2 • Give diuretics TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a serious complication that can occur during or within 6 hours after receiving a blood transfusion (or up to 72 hours in delayed cases). It's characterized by acute, noncardiogenic pulmonary edema with hypoxia, making it the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths reported to the FDA. The condition typically presents with symptoms like fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and difficulty breathing, along with bilateral infiltrates visible on chest X-rays. TRALI occurs when antibodies in donor blood react with the recipient's blood cells, or when stored blood products accumulate inflammatory mediators, leading to damage in the pulmonary blood vessels and fluid leakage into the lungs. Continue transfusion but at a slower rate (Option A): Continuing transfusion even at a slower rate would worsen fluid overload Administer acetaminophen and continue transfusion (Option C): Acetaminophen would not address the underlying fluid overload Stop transfusion and start steroids (Option D): Steroids are not indicated in the management of TACO according to the provided information Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 895

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute dyspnea and bilateral crackles. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate 110/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention, bilateral pedal edema, and an S3 gallop. Chest X-ray is given below. His pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is 25 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) IV furosemide and nitrates Explanation: The case presents classic cardiogenic pulmonary edema with characteristic features including elevated PCWP (>18 mmHg), JVD, pedal edema, and S3 gallop. Also the chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and mild pulmonary edema with widening of the vascular pedicle (red arrow) and interstitial prominence. questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea, productive cough, and weight loss. Physical examination reveals a barrel chest, decreased breath sounds, and prolonged expiration. Chest X-ray is given below. His FEV1/FVC ratio is 0.65 and doesn't improve with bronchodilators. Which of the following is the most likely pathological finding in this patient?

options.A: Inflammation of bronchial walls with mucus hypersecretion
options.B: Permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to terminal bronchioles
options.C: Bronchial wall thickening with reversible airway obstruction

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to terminal bronchioles Explanation: The clinical scenario of a smoker with dyspnea, cough, weight loss along with barrel chest and reduced FEV1/FVC ratio with an x-ray image showing hyperinflation & increased lung volume suggests classic emphysema where Permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to terminal bronchioles are seen. The diagnosis of emphysema in this case is supported by multiple key findings: 1. questions.question: A 55-year-old man with a history of deep vein thrombosis is brought to the emergency department by his wife after he suddenly developed sharp, stabbing chest pain and shortness of breath while at home. He describes the pain as worse when taking a deep breath. The X-ray taken is displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Pulmonary infarction due to pulmonary embolism

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pulmonary infarction due to pulmonary embolism Explanation: The wedge-shaped opacity pointing toward the hilum is characteristic of Hampton's Hump , a classic radiologic finding associated with pulmonary infarction due to pulmonary embolism (PE). The sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain and the patient's history of DVT make PE the most likely diagnosis. Hampton's Hump is a radiologic sign seen in cases of pulmonary embolism (PE) and is indicative of a pulmonary infarction. Appearance : Seen on chest X-rays as a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity . The apex of the wedge points toward the hilum or occluding vessel. Timing : Typically not visible within the first 24 hours after the embolus lodges in the pulmonary artery. Appears later as parenchymal infarction develops, and may take 3–5 weeks or longer to resolve . Resolution and Complications : A residual band-like opacity due to scarring or pleural thickening may persist. The infarcted area can sometimes become secondarily infected , leading to cavitation or abscess. This may also occur due to septic emboli. Differential : Hampton’s Hump can also result from edema or hemorrhage rather than infarction. questions.question: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the pulmonary clinic with a history of progressive shortness of breath and a chronic cough. He is a long-term smoker and has a family history of respiratory diseases. A spirometry test is performed, and the flow-volume loop is plotted. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms and the shape of his flow-volume loop?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Obstructive lung disease Explanation: The scooped-out pattern on expiration is a classic finding in obstructive diseases like COPD, which often presents in smokers with chronic symptoms like the patient. Flow-volume loops can display distinct patterns, each associated with different types of respiratory conditions. Types of Flow-Volume Loops: Flow volume curve loop types and examples: Loop Type Expiratory Curve Inspiratory Curve Example Conditions Normal Symmetrical, peaked Symmetrical, rounded Healthy lungs (Option C ruled out) Obstructive Scooped (concave) Normal COPD, asthma Restrictive Narrow, peaked Narrow, peaked Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion (Option A ruled out) Fixed Upper Airway Obstruction Flattened (box-like) Flattened (box-like) Tracheal stenosis, large goiter (Option D ruled out) Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction Normal Flattened Vocal cord dysfunction, laryngeal tumor Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction Flattened Normal Tracheomalacia, bronchogenic tumor
